summary: This is a confidential memorandum from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, dated July 23, 2019, detailing an incident involving inmate Jeffrey Epstein. It reports that Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell with a noose around his neck, was revived, and subsequently claimed his cellmate had attempted to kill and extort him. The report was immediately escalated to a lieutenant.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found unresponsive in his cell with a noose around his neck. After being revived, he claimed his cellmate tried to kill and extort him.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: The officer to whom the reporting officer immediately reported Epstein's allegations about his cellmate.

connections.description: The reporting officer informed the lieutenant about Epstein's allegations against his cellmate.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a noose around his neck, appearing unresponsive. He was revived and taken for medical assessment, then placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Alleges Cellmate Threats
events.description: After being revived, Epstein told the reporting officer that his cellmate had tried to kill him, had been extorting him for money with threats of violence for a week, and that he had only told his lawyer.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center with a noose around his neck.
Epstein was revived, medically assessed, and placed on suicide watch.
Epstein claimed his cellmate had tried to kill him and had been extorting him with threats of violence for a week.
Epstein stated he had not reported the threats to correctional staff, only to his lawyer, because his cellmate claimed officers would not report any assault due to Epstein's charges.
The reporting officer immediately reported Epstein's allegations to a lieutenant.
